title: Scripting
descrption: Adversaries may use scripts to aid in operations and perform multiple actions that would otherwise be manual. Scripting is useful for speeding up operational tasks and reducing the time required to gain access to critical resources. Some scripting languages may be used to bypass process monitoring mechanisms by directly interacting with the operating system at an API level instead of calling other programs. Common scripting languages for Windows include VBScript and PowerShell but could also be in the form of command-line batch scripts.Scripts can be embedded inside Office documents as macros that can be set to execute when files used in Spearphishing Attachment and other types of spearphishing are opened. Malicious embedded macros are an alternative means of execution than software exploitation through Exploitation for Client Execution, where adversaries will rely on macros being allowed or that the user will accept to activate them.Many popular offensive frameworks exist which use forms of scripting for security testers and adversaries alike. Metasploit [1], Veil [2], and PowerSploit [3] are three examples that are popular among penetration testers for exploit and post-compromise operations and include many features for evading defenses. Some adversaries are known to use PowerShell. [4]
Data Sources: Process monitoring, File monitoring, Process command-line parameters
Defense Bypassed: Process whitelisting, Data Execution Prevention, Exploit Prevention

related.Name: APT1
related.Description: APT1 has used batch scripting to automate execution of commands.[76]

related.Name: APT19
related.Description: APT19 downloaded and launched code within a SCT file.[85]

related.Name: APT28
related.Description: An APT28 loader Trojan uses a batch script to run its payload. The group has also used macros to execute payloads.[107][27][108][109]

related.Name: APT29
related.Description: APT29 has used encoded PowerShell scripts uploaded to CozyCar installations to download and install SeaDuke, as well as to evade defenses.[32][69]

related.Name: APT3
related.Description: APT3 has used PowerShell on victim systems to download and run payloads after exploitation.[84]

related.Name: APT32
related.Description: APT32 has used macros, PowerShell scripts, COM scriptlets, and VBS scripts.[110][40]

related.Name: APT37
related.Description: APT37 executes shellcode and a script to decode Base64 strings.[99]

related.Name: APT39
related.Description: APT39 utilized custom scripts to perform internal reconnaissance.[118]

related.Name: Astaroth
related.Description: Astaroth uses JavaScript to perform its core functionalities.[49]

related.Name: Bisonal
related.Description: Bisonal's dropper creates VBS scripts on the victim’s machine.[16]

related.Name: BRONZE BUTLER
related.Description: BRONZE BUTLER has used VBS, VBE, and batch scripts for execution.[92]

related.Name: China Chopper
related.Description: China Chopper's server component is a text based payload available in a variety of scripting languages.  [52]

related.Name: Cobalt Group
related.Description: Cobalt Group has sent Word OLE compound documents with malicious obfuscated VBA macros that will run upon user execution and executed JavaScript scriptlets on the victim's machine. The group has also used an exploit toolkit known as Threadkit that launches .bat files.[101][102][103][104][105][106]

related.Name: Cobalt Strike
related.Description: Cobalt Strike can use PowerShell, Python, VBA, PowerSploit, other scripting frameworks to perform execution.[5][6]

related.Name: CoinTicker
related.Description: CoinTicker executes a bash script to establish a reverse shell and a Python script to download its second stage.[53]

related.Name: Comnie
related.Description: Comnie executes BAT and VBS scripts.[14]

related.Name: Dark Caracal
related.Description: Dark Caracal has used macros in Word documents that would download a second stage if executed.[70]

related.Name: DarkComet
related.Description: DarkComet can execute various types of scripts on the victim’s machine.[28]

related.Name: Darkhotel
related.Description: Darkhotel has dropped an mspaint.lnk shortcut to disk which launches a shell script that downloads and executes a file.[100]

related.Name: DealersChoice
related.Description: DealersChoice makes modifications to open-source scripts from GitHub and executes them on the victim’s machine.[17]

related.Name: Deep Panda
related.Description: Deep Panda has used PowerShell scripts to download and execute programs in memory, without writing to disk.[4]

related.Name: Denis
related.Description: Denis executes shellcode on the victim's machine.[40]

related.Name: Dragonfly 2.0
related.Description: Dragonfly 2.0 used various types of scripting to perform operations, including Python and batch scripts. The group was observed installing Python 2.7 on a victim.[87][88]

related.Name: Emotet
related.Description: Emotet has sent Microsoft Word documents with embedded macros that will invoke scripts to download additional payloads.[42][43][44][45][46]

related.Name: Empire
related.Description: Empire has modules for executing scripts.[10]

related.Name: EvilBunny
related.Description: EvilBunny has an integrated scripting engine to download and execute Lua scripts.[65]

related.Name: Exaramel for Windows
related.Description: Exaramel for Windows has a command to execute VBS and GO scripts on the victim’s machine.[20]

related.Name: FELIXROOT
related.Description: FELIXROOT executes batch scripts on the victim’s machine.[35]

related.Name: FIN10
related.Description: FIN10 has executed malicious .bat files containing PowerShell commands.[83]

related.Name: FIN4
related.Description: FIN4 has used VBA macros to display a dialog box and collect victim credentials.[111][112]

related.Name: FIN5
related.Description: FIN5 scans processes on all victim systems in the environment and uses automated scripts to pull back the results.[95]

related.Name: FIN6
related.Description: FIN6 has used a Metasploit PowerShell module to download and execute shellcode and to set up a local listener. FIN6 has also used scripting to iterate through a list of compromised PoS systems, copy data to a log file, and remove the original data files.[90][91]

related.Name: FIN7
related.Description: FIN7 used SQL, VBS and JavaScript scripts to help perform tasks on the victim's machine.[115][62]

related.Name: FIN8
related.Description: FIN8 has used a Batch file to automate frequently executed post compromise cleanup activities.[86]

related.Name: Gallmaker
related.Description: Gallmaker used PowerShell scripts for execution.[116]

related.Name: Gamaredon Group
related.Description: Gamaredon Group has used various batch scripts to establish C2, download additional files, and conduct other functions.[97]

related.Name: Gorgon Group
related.Description: Gorgon Group has used macros in Spearphishing Attachments as well as executed VBScripts on victim machines.[117]

related.Name: Helminth
related.Description: One version of Helminth consists of VBScript and PowerShell scripts. The malware also uses batch scripting.[37]

related.Name: HiddenWasp
related.Description: HiddenWasp uses a script to automate tasks on the victim's machine and to assist in execution.[64]

related.Name: Honeybee
related.Description: Honeybee embeds a Visual Basic script within a malicious Word document as part of initial access; the script is executed when the Word document is opened. The actors also used batch scripting.[89]

related.Name: JCry
related.Description: JCry has used VBS scripts.[61]

related.Name: JHUHUGIT
related.Description: JHUHUGIT uses a .bat file to execute a .dll.[27]

related.Name: jRAT
related.Description: jRAT has been distributed as HTA files with VBScript+JScript.[54]

related.Name: Ke3chang
related.Description: Ke3chang has used batch scripts in its malware to install persistence mechanisms.[98]

related.Name: KeyBoy
related.Description: KeyBoy uses Python and VBS scripts for installing files and performing execution.[60]

related.Name: Keydnap
related.Description: Keydnap uses Python for scripting to execute additional commands.[22]

related.Name: Koadic
related.Description: Koadic performs most of its operations using Windows Script Host (Jscript and VBScript) and runs arbitrary shellcode .[8]

related.Name: Lazarus Group
related.Description: A Destover-like variant used by Lazarus Group uses a batch file mechanism to delete its binaries from the system.[13]

related.Name: Leafminer
related.Description: Leafminer infected victims using JavaScript code.[93]

related.Name: Leviathan
related.Description: Leviathan has used multiple types of scripting for execution, including JavaScript, JavaScript Scriptlets in XML, and VBScript.[31]

related.Name: Machete
related.Description: Machete uses Python scripts. [67][68]

related.Name: Machete
related.Description: Machete used multiple compiled Python scripts on the victim’s system.[124]

related.Name: Magic Hound
related.Description: Magic Hound malware has used .vbs scripts for execution.[71]

related.Name: menuPass
related.Description: menuPass has used malicious macros embedded inside Office documents to execute files.[81][82]

related.Name: MoonWind
related.Description: MoonWind uses batch scripts for various purposes, including to restart and uninstall itself.[11]

related.Name: MuddyWater
related.Description: MuddyWater has used VBScript and JavaScript files to execute its POWERSTATS payload. MuddyWater has also used Microsoft scriptlets, macros, and PowerShell scripts.[[72][73][74][75][21]

related.Name: NanHaiShu
related.Description: NanHaiShu executes additional Jscript and VBScript code on the victim's machine.[33]

related.Name: NanoCore
related.Description: NanoCore uses VBS and JavaScript files.[29]

related.Name: NavRAT
related.Description: NavRAT loads malicious shellcode and executes it in memory.[36]

related.Name: OceanSalt
related.Description: OceanSalt has been executed via malicious macros.[41]

related.Name: OilRig
related.Description: OilRig has used various types of scripting for execution, including .bat and .vbs scripts. The group has also used macros to deliver malware such as QUADAGENT and OopsIE.[78][79][25][18][80]

related.Name: OopsIE
related.Description: OopsIE creates and uses a VBScript as part of its persistent execution.[25][26]

related.Name: Orz
related.Description: Orz can execute commands with script as well as execute JavaScript.[31]

related.Name: OSX/Shlayer
related.Description: OSX/Shlayer can use bash scripts to check the macOS version and download payloads.[66]

related.Name: OSX_OCEANLOTUS.D
related.Description: OSX_OCEANLOTUS.D uses macros for execution as well as VBS and PowerShell scripts.[39]

related.Name: Patchwork
related.Description: Patchwork used Visual Basic Scripts (VBS), JavaScript code, batch files, and .SCT files on victim machines.[113][114]

related.Name: PowerStallion
related.Description: PowerStallion uses PowerShell loops to iteratively check for available commands in its OneDrive C2 server.[63]

related.Name: POWERSTATS
related.Description: POWERSTATS can use VBScript (VBE), PowerShell, and JavaScript code for execution.[21]

related.Name: Proton
related.Description: Proton uses macOS' .command file type to script actions.[34]

related.Name: Proxysvc
related.Description: Proxysvc uses a batch file to delete itself.[13]

related.Name: PUNCHBUGGY
related.Description: PUNCHBUGGY has used PowerShell, python, and shellcode scripts.[59]

related.Name: Pupy
related.Description: Pupy can use an add on feature when creating payloads that allows you to create custom Python scripts ("scriptlets") to perform tasks offline (without requiring a session) such as sandbox detection, adding persistence, etc.[7]

related.Name: QUADAGENT
related.Description: QUADAGENT uses VBScripts and batch scripts.[18]

related.Name: Rancor
related.Description: Rancor has used shell and VBS scripts as well as embedded macros for execution.[94]

related.Name: Remcos
related.Description: Remcos uses Python scripts.[9]

related.Name: Remexi
related.Description: Remexi uses AutoIt and VBS scripts throughout its execution process.[51]

related.Name: Revenge RAT
related.Description: Revenge RAT executes scripts on the victim's machine.[55][56]

related.Name: RogueRobin
related.Description: To assist in establishing persistence, RogueRobin creates %APPDATA%\OneDrive.bat and saves the following string to it:powershell.exe -WindowStyle Hidden -exec bypass -File "%APPDATA%\OneDrive.ps1". RogueRobin also uses Windows Script Components.[23][24]

related.Name: RunningRAT
related.Description: RunningRAT uses a batch file to kill a security program task and then attempts to remove itself.[12]

related.Name: SamSam
related.Description: SamSam uses custom batch scripts to execute some of its components.[48]

related.Name: SeaDuke
related.Description: SeaDuke uses a module to execute Mimikatz with PowerShell to perform Pass the Ticket.[32]

related.Name: Silence
related.Description: Silence has used JS, VBS, and PowerShell scripts.[120]

related.Name: Smoke Loader
related.Description: Smoke Loader adds a Visual Basic script in the Startup folder to deploy the payload.[38]

related.Name: SpeakUp
related.Description: SpeakUp uses Perl and Python scripts.[50]

related.Name: SQLRat
related.Description: SQLRat has used SQL to execute JavaScript and VB scripts on the host system.[62]

related.Name: Stealth Falcon
related.Description: Stealth Falcon malware uses PowerShell and WMI to script data collection and command execution on the victim.[77]

related.Name: StoneDrill
related.Description: StoneDrill has several VBS scripts used throughout the malware's lifecycle.  [57]

related.Name: TA459
related.Description: TA459 has a VBScript for execution.[96]

related.Name: TA505
related.Description: TA505 has used PowerShell, VBS, and JavaScript for code execution.[121][122]

related.Name: TrickBot
related.Description: TrickBot has used macros in Excel documents to download and deploy the malware on the user’s machine.[47]

related.Name: Turla
related.Description: Turla has used PowerShell and VBS scripts throughout its operations.   [123]

related.Name: TYPEFRAME
related.Description: TYPEFRAME can uninstall malware components using a batch script. Additionally, a malicious Word document used for delivery uses VBA macros for execution.[19]

related.Name: Ursnif
related.Description: Ursnif droppers have used VBA macros and PowerShell to download and execute the malware's full executable payload.[58]

related.Name: WIRTE
related.Description: WIRTE has used VBS and PowerShell scripts throughout its operation.    [119]

related.Name: Xbash
related.Description: Xbash can execute malicious JavaScript and VBScript payloads on the victim’s machine.[30]

related.Name: Zeus Panda
related.Description: Zeus Panda can launch remote scripts on the victim’s machine.[15]

Configure Office security settings enable Protected View, to execute within a sandbox environment, and to block macros through Group Policy. Other types of virtualization and application microsegmentation may also mitigate the impact of compromise.

related.Mitigation: Disable or Remove Feature or Program
related.Description: Turn off unused features or restrict access to scripting engines such as VBScript or scriptable administration frameworks such as PowerShell.
